subject: Physics

figures.description: Fig. 1 shows two convex lenses labeled Objective lens and Eye lens with rays drawn, typical of an astronomical telescope arrangement.
Fig. 2 shows a block on an incline at angle θ with forces labeled: W vertically downward, R normal reaction, and F limiting friction along the plane.
Fig. 3 shows a particle entering between parallel plates in an electric field and following a curved trajectory.
Four small diagrams (A–D) of standing wave patterns in tubes; used to select when tube length equals one wavelength.
Diagram of a maximum and minimum thermometer with regions labeled P, Q, R and marks X and Y.
Diagram showing six identical 2 V cells connected in some series/opposition arrangement for determining effective emf.

questions.question: A piece of rubber 10 cm long stretches 6 mm when a load of 100 N is hung from it. What is the strain?
questions.explanation: Strain \(=\frac{\Delta L}{L}=\frac{6\,\text{mm}}{10\,\text{cm}}=\frac{0.6\,\text{cm}}{10\,\text{cm}}=0.06\). The correct strain is 0.06, which is not among the options shown; the listed \(6.0\times 10^{-3}\) equals 0.006. Therefore, there is a mismatch between the data and options in the image.

questions.question: The diagram above shows the lens arrangement in
questions.explanation: The diagram shows an objective lens forming an intermediate image and an eyepiece lens producing a final image for viewing—typical of an astronomical telescope setup.

questions.question: What is the total resistance in the below diagram?
questions.explanation: The resistor network diagram for Question 3 is not fully visible/legible in the provided image crop (only the answer options are visible alongside a partial sketch), so the total resistance cannot be computed from the upload.

questions.question: A body of mass 6 kg rests on an inclined plane. The normal reaction R and the limiting frictional force is F as shown in the diagram (Fig. 2). If F is 30 N and g = 10 m s\(^{-2}\), then the angle of inclination θ is
questions.explanation: At rest, component of weight down the plane is balanced by friction: \(mg\sin\theta = F\). Here \(mg=6\times 10=60\,N\). So \(60\sin\theta = 30\Rightarrow \sin\theta=\tfrac{1}{2}\Rightarrow \theta=30^\circ\).

questions.question: The speed of light in air is \(3.0\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}\). Its speed in glass having index of refraction of 1.65 is
questions.explanation: Refractive index \(n=\frac{c}{v}\Rightarrow v=\frac{c}{n}=\frac{3.0\times 10^8}{1.65}=1.818\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}\approx 1.82\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1}\).

questions.question: Longitudinal waves do not exhibit
questions.explanation: Polarization is a property of transverse waves; longitudinal waves cannot be polarized.

questions.question: A device that converts sound energy into electrical energy is

options.text: the horn of a motor car

questions.explanation: A microphone converts sound vibrations into electrical signals.

questions.question: A good calorimeter should be of

options.text: low specific heat capacity and low heat conductivity
high specific heat capacity and low heat conductivity
high specific heat capacity and low heat conductivity
low specific heat capacity and high heat conductivity

questions.explanation: A calorimeter should absorb little heat itself (low heat capacity) and reduce heat exchange with surroundings (poor conductor).

questions.question: Which of the following is most strongly deflected by a magnetic field?
questions.explanation: β-particles are charged (electrons/positrons) with small mass, so they are strongly deflected. γ-rays and X-rays are uncharged electromagnetic waves and are not deflected.

questions.question: If a beaker is filled with water, it is observed that the surface of the water is not horizontal at the glass-water interface. This behaviour is due to
questions.explanation: The curved meniscus results from surface tension and adhesion between water and glass.

questions.question: A dynamo primarily conducts
questions.explanation: A dynamo (generator) converts mechanical energy to electrical energy by electromagnetic induction.

questions.question: A particle is injected perpendicularly into an electric field. It travels along a curved path as depicted in the figure 3. The particle is
questions.explanation: A curved path in an electric field indicates the particle is charged. The direction of curvature shown is toward the positive plate, indicating a negatively charged particle: an electron.

questions.question: In which of the following diagrams is the length of the tube equal to one wavelength?
questions.explanation: A tube length equals one wavelength when the standing-wave pattern contains one complete cycle along the tube (two loops). Diagram D shows two loops filling the tube, corresponding to \(L=\lambda\).

questions.question: A calibrated potentiometer is used to measure the e.m.f. of a cell because the

options.text: internal resistance of a cell is small compared with that of the potentiometer
potentiometer takes no current from the cell
resistance of the potentiometer is less than that of a voltmeter

questions.explanation: At balance point, a potentiometer measures emf without drawing current from the cell, avoiding internal resistance errors.

questions.question: Which of the following is a vector?
questions.explanation: Electric field has both magnitude and direction; the others are scalars.

questions.question: The photocell works on the principle of the

options.text: emission of protons by incident electrons
emission of electrons by incident radiation

questions.explanation: A photocell is based on the photoelectric effect: emission of electrons due to incident light.

questions.question: When an atom loses or gains a charge, it becomes
questions.explanation: Loss or gain of electrons produces a charged atom (ion).

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics of a wave is used in the measurement of the depth of the sea?
questions.explanation: Echo sounding uses reflection of sound waves from the seabed.

questions.question:
Which of the following are produced after a nuclear fusion process?
I. One heavy nucleus
II. Neutrons
III. Protons
IV. Energy
questions.explanation: Fusion combines light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus and releases energy. Neutrons/protons may or may not appear depending on the reaction, but the general outcomes are a heavier nucleus and energy.

questions.question: Two similar kettles containing equal masses of boiling water are placed on a table. If the surface of one is highly polished and the surface of the other is covered with soot, which of the following observations is correct?

options.text: The two kettles will cool down at the same rate
The polished kettle cools down more quickly by conduction
The kettle covered with soot cools down more quickly because it is a good radiator of heat
The kettle covered with soot cools down more quickly by the process of heat convection

questions.explanation: A dull black surface (soot) is a better emitter of thermal radiation than a polished surface, so it cools faster by radiation.

questions.question: Total eclipse of the sun occurs when the

options.text: moon is between the sun and the earth
sun is between the moon and the earth
the earth is between the moon and the sun

questions.explanation: A solar eclipse occurs when the moon comes between the sun and the earth.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of colours gives the widest separation in the spectrum of white light?
questions.explanation: Red deviates least and violet most, giving maximum separation.

questions.question: Which of the following with respect to a body performing simple harmonic motion are in phase?

options.text: Displacement and velocity of the body
Displacement and force on the body
Velocity and acceleration of the body
Force acting on the body and the acceleration

questions.explanation: In SHM, \(F=ma\) and both are proportional to \(-x\), so force and acceleration are in phase. Displacement is 180° out of phase with acceleration/force, and velocity is 90° out of phase with displacement.

questions.question: A uniform metre rule weighing 0.5 V is to be pivoted on a knife-edge at the 30 cm-mark. Where will a force of 2 N be placed from the pivot to balance the metre rule?
questions.explanation: The question contains a unit/typo: the metre rule 'weighing 0.5 V' should be weight in newtons (likely 0.5 N) or mass (0.5 kg). Without a consistent weight value, the torque balance distance cannot be determined reliably from the provided text.

questions.question: A solid weighs 10.0 N in air, 6.0 N when fully immersed in water and 7.0 N when fully immersed in a certain liquid X. Calculate the relative density of the liquid.
questions.explanation: Upthrust in water = 10 − 6 = 4 N. Upthrust in liquid X = 10 − 7 = 3 N. Relative density \(=\frac{\rho_X}{\rho_{water}}=\frac{\text{upthrust in X}}{\text{upthrust in water}}=\frac{3}{4}\).

questions.question: The diagram above shows a maximum and minimum thermometer divided into three portions P, Q and r which of the following is true about the respective content of p, q and R?
questions.explanation: The thermometer diagram is too unclear to confidently identify which section corresponds to mercury/alcohol/air from the labels P, Q, R and the markers X and Y. Therefore the correct option cannot be determined from the upload.

questions.question: The process of energy production in the sun is
questions.explanation: The sun produces energy mainly by nuclear fusion of hydrogen into helium.

questions.question: The particle responsible for nuclear fusion in a nuclear reactor is
questions.explanation: Reactors operate by nuclear fission, not fusion. In fission reactors, neutrons initiate the chain reaction, but the question states fusion, creating a mismatch. Therefore a uniquely correct answer cannot be asserted from the given text.

questions.question: If the uncertainty in the measurement of the position of a particle is \(5\times 10^{-10}\,m\), the uncertainty in the momentum of the particle is
questions.explanation: Heisenberg: \(\Delta x\,\Delta p \ge \frac{h}{4\pi}\). Using \(h=6.6\times 10^{-34}\,J s\): \(\Delta p \approx \frac{6.6\times 10^{-34}}{4\pi\times 5\times 10^{-10}}\approx 1.05\times 10^{-25}\,N s\). None matches exactly; if the paper uses \(\Delta x\Delta p \approx \frac{h}{2\pi}\), then \(\Delta p\approx \frac{6.6\times 10^{-34}}{2\pi\times 5\times 10^{-10}}\approx 2.1\times 10^{-25}\,N s\). Options are ~10^-24; closest is D (3.30×10^-24) but the numerical mismatch suggests either different constants/rounding were intended.

questions.question: The change in volume when 450 kg of ice is completely melted is [density of ice = 900 kg m^-3, density of water = 1000 kg m^-3]
questions.explanation: Volume of ice: \(V_i=\frac{450}{900}=0.50\,m^3\). Volume of water: \(V_w=\frac{450}{1000}=0.45\,m^3\). Change \(\Delta V=V_i-V_w=0.05\,m^3\). That matches option D, not B.

questions.question: When impurities are added to semiconductor
questions.explanation: The stem is incomplete in the image (it does not say what property changes). Without the missing words, no option can be chosen.

questions.question: The process through which free electrons leave the hot surface of hot metal is known as
questions.explanation: Emission of electrons from a heated metal surface is thermionic emission.

questions.question: The production of pure spectrum could easily be achieved using a

options.text: Triangular prism with two concave lens
Triangular prism with two convex lens

questions.explanation: A pure spectrum is produced by using a collimator (convex lens) to form a parallel beam into the prism and a convex lens (telescope) to focus/observe the spectrum; hence prism with two convex lenses.

questions.question: A short chain is something attached to the back of a petrol tanker to

options.text: Conduct excess charges to the earth
Ensure the balancing of the tanker
Caution the driver when over speeding

questions.explanation: The chain grounds the tanker to discharge static electricity, preventing sparks.

questions.question: A perfect emitter or absorber of radiant energy is a
questions.explanation: A black body is an ideal absorber and emitter.

questions.question: Six identical cells, each of e.m.f 2 V are connected as shown above. The effective e.m.f. of the cell is
questions.explanation: The cell-connection diagram is not sufficiently clear to determine which cells aid/oppose, so the effective e.m.f cannot be computed reliably from the upload.

questions.question: If a pump is capable of lifting 5000 kg of water through a vertical height of 60 m in 50 mins, the power of the pump is
questions.explanation: Work \(W=mgh=5000\times 10\times 60=3.0\times 10^6\,J\). Time \(t=50\,min=3000\,s\). Power \(P=\frac{3.0\times 10^6}{3000}=1.0\times 10^3\,W\). None of the options matches 1000 W; option B (3.3×10^3) and D (3.3×10^2) are not equal. This indicates an inconsistency between the printed data and options.

questions.question: The distance between two successive crest of a wave is 15 cm and the velocity is 300 m s^-1. Calculate the frequency.
questions.explanation: Wavelength \(\lambda=15\,cm=0.15\,m\). Frequency \(f=\frac{v}{\lambda}=\frac{300}{0.15}=2000\,Hz=2.0\times 10^3\,Hz\).

questions.question: An electric lamp marked 240 V, 60 Watts is left to operate for an hour. How much energy is generated by the filament?
questions.explanation: Energy \(E=Pt\). \(P=60\,W\), \(t=1\,h=3600\,s\). \(E=60\times 3600=216000\,J=2.16\times 10^5\,J\). That matches option B, not D.

questions.question: In comparing the camera and human eye, the film of the camera functions as the
questions.explanation: The retina is the light-sensitive surface of the eye; camera film/sensor plays the same role.
